title: Getting Started with PythonCK
text:
Welcome to the PythonCK tutorials! These step-by-step guides will help you understand the core concepts and learn how to use the library effectively.








Let‚Äôs import the necessary modules:









Tensor coordinates are the foundation of how we address multi-dimensional data:









Tensor descriptors provide metadata about tensor layout and properties:









Buffer views provide low-level control over memory access patterns:









Learn how data is organized and processed in tiles:









Explore how tensor adaptors enable complex transformations:









Now that you‚Äôve learned the basics, explore specific concepts in detail:

Tensor Adaptor - Deep dive into tensor transformations
Tile Operations - Advanced tiling strategies
Buffer Management - Memory access optimization




Try modifying the examples above! Change the tensor dimensions, tile sizes, or transformation types to see how the system behaves. All code runs directly in your browser, so feel free to experiment.



Here are some common usage patterns you‚Äôll encounter:

Creating multi-dimensional coordinates for indexing
Setting up tile distributions for parallel processing
Applying tensor adaptors for data transformations
Managing buffer views for memory optimization

Each concept builds on the previous ones, creating a powerful framework for GPU kernel development.

title: Tensor Coordinates
text:
Tensor coordinates provide a powerful abstraction for multi-dimensional indexing with support for complex transformations. They form the foundation for all tensor operations in PythonCK.




A MultiIndex represents a multi-dimensional index with a specific number of dimensions:









A TensorCoordinate extends MultiIndex with transformation capabilities:































Tensor coordinates are used throughout PythonCK:

Buffer Views use coordinates to access memory locations
Tensor Descriptors transform coordinates through layout changes

Tile Distributions map coordinates between different spaces
Sweep Operations iterate through coordinate ranges





Explore Buffer Views to see how coordinates access memory
Learn about Tensor Descriptors for coordinate transformations
Understand Tile Distribution for parallel coordinate mapping

The coordinate system provides the mathematical foundation that enables all the advanced tensor operations in PythonCK.

title: Tensor Coordinates
text:
Key Concepts

MultiIndex: Basic multi-dimensional coordinate representation
Hidden Dimensions: Internal coordinate space that enables transformations
Top/Bottom Mapping: How visible tensor dimensions map to internal coordinates
Linear Offset: Final memory address for element access

Tensor coordinates provide the foundation for all other PythonCK operations by giving you precise control over how multi-dimensional data is addressed and transformed.

title: Composable-Kernels Python Documentation
text:
Welcome to PythonCK, a Python implementation of tensor operations and concepts from the AMD Composable Kernels library. This package provides educational implementations that focus on clarity and understanding rather than performance.


New to PythonCK? Follow our structured learning path to understand all concepts:


A step-by-step guide that builds from basic concepts to advanced GPU thread coordination, culminating in understanding the complete tile_distr_thread_mapping.py example.







Buffer Views - Memory buffer abstraction
Tensor Coordinates - Multi-dimensional indexing
Tensor Descriptors - Layout transformations
Tensor Views - Unified tensor access





Tile Distribution Encoding - How data is distributed
Tile Distribution - Parallel processing coordination
Static Distributed Tensors - Thread-local data





Tile Windows - Windowed tensor access
Sweep Operations - Iterating over distributed data
Thread Mapping - Understanding the complete pipeline





pytensor/                    # Core tensor operations
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ buffer_view.py          # Memory abstraction
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tensor_coordinate.py    # Multi-dimensional indexing
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tensor_descriptor.py    # Layout transformations  
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tensor_view.py          # Unified access interface
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tile_distribution.py    # Data distribution
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tile_window.py          # Windowed access
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ sweep_tile.py           # Coordinated iteration
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ ...

tensor_transforms/          # Analysis tools
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ parser.py              # Descriptor parsing
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ analyzer.py            # Transformation analysis
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ ...

tile_distribution/          # Visualization tools
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ parser.py              # C++ encoding parsing
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ visualizer.py          # Interactive visualization
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ ...



PythonCK implements several interconnected concepts:

Tensors are multi-dimensional arrays with flexible layouts
Coordinates provide multi-dimensional indexing with transformations
Distributions define how data is spread across parallel processing elements
Tiles represent chunks of data processed by individual threads/warps
Sweeps iterate over distributed data in a coordinated manner

The ultimate goal is understanding how GPU threads coordinate to process large tensors efficiently, as demonstrated in the complete example at tile_distr_thread_mapping.py.



Jump right in with interactive examples:









Choose your learning approach:

üéì Structured Path - Follow the complete 10-step progression
üîç Concept-Driven - Explore individual concepts as needed
üíª Code-First - Jump into the API documentation
üéÆ Interactive - Try hands-on tutorials




This documentation includes:

üèÉ Live Code Execution - Run Python code directly in your browser
üì± Responsive Design - Works on desktop and mobile
üåì Dark/Light Mode - Toggle between themes
üîç Full-Text Search - Find what you need quickly
üìã Copy Code - One-click code copying

Ready to dive deeper? Start with our Complete Learning Path or jump to any concept that interests you.

title: Composable-Kernels Python Documentation
text:
What is Composable Kernels?
Composable Kernels (CK) is a performance portable programming model for writing high performance GPU kernels for machine learning workloads across multiple architectures including GCDCore, CDNA, RDNA architectures, and various other GPU architectures.
This Python implementation allows you to:

Understand the core concepts behind tensor operations
Experiment with tensor transformations interactively
Visualize how data flows through different tensor operations
Learn GPU kernel design patterns

Sweeps iterate over distributed data in a coordinated manner

The ultimate goal is understanding how GPU threads coordinate to process large tensors efficiently, as demonstrated in the complete example at tile_distr_thread_mapping.py.

title: Buffer View
text:
Buffer views provide a unified abstraction for accessing memory across different address spaces and with various access patterns. They form the lowest level of the PythonCK memory hierarchy.











































































































Buffer views are the foundation for:

Tensor Views - Combine buffers with tensor descriptors for structured access
Tile Windows - Provide windowed access to buffer regions
Static Distributed Tensors - Thread-local buffer management
Memory Operations - All tensor operations ultimately access memory through buffer views





Learn about Tensor Coordinates for multi-dimensional indexing
Explore Tensor Views to see how buffers combine with descriptors
Understand Static Distributed Tensors for parallel buffer management

Buffer views provide the essential memory abstraction that enables all higher-level tensor operations in PythonCK.

title: Buffer View
text:
Key Concepts

Address Spaces: Different memory hierarchies (Global, LDS, VGPR)
Vectorized Access: Efficient multi-element operations
Bounds Checking: Safe memory access with invalid element handling
Memory Operations: SET, ADD, ATOMIC operations
GPU Memory Model: Abstractions for GPU memory hierarchies

Buffer views provide the low-level foundation for efficient tensor operations by abstracting memory access patterns and supporting GPU-specific memory hierarchies.

Explore Tensor Views to see how buffers combine with descriptors
Understand Static Distributed Tensors for parallel buffer management

Buffer views provide the essential memory abstraction that enables all higher-level tensor operations in PythonCK.

title: API Reference
text:
Complete reference documentation for all PythonCK modules and classes.




The main tensor operations module containing all core functionality.

tensor_coordinate - Multi-dimensional coordinate handling
tensor_descriptor - Tensor layout and metadata
tensor_adaptor - Tensor transformations and adaptations
tensor_view - Views and slicing operations
buffer_view - Low-level memory access patterns






tile_distribution - Data distribution across tiles
tile_distribution_encoding - Encoding schemes for tile distribution
tile_window - Windowed access to tile data
tile_window_linear - Linear tile window operations
tile_window_utils - Utility functions for tile windows





shuffle_tile - Data shuffling and rearrangement
sweep_tile - Iterative tile processing
store_tile - Tile storage operations
update_tile - In-place tile updates
tile_scatter_gather - Scatter/gather operations





static_distributed_tensor - Compile-time optimized tensors
space_filling_curve - Advanced memory access patterns
static_encoding_pattern - Static encoding strategies






Higher-level transformation utilities and examples.

analyzer - Tensor operation analysis
parser - Parsing tensor expressions
examples - Common transformation patterns




Advanced tile distribution strategies and visualization.

parser - Tile distribution parsing
visualizer - Tile distribution visualization
examples - Tile distribution examples
























Class
Purpose
Key Methods




TensorCoordinate
Multi-dimensional indexing
__init__(), get_element_count()


TensorDescriptor
Tensor metadata
calculate_offset(), get_strides()


TensorAdaptor
Tensor transformations
transform_coordinate(), get_output_shape()


BufferView
Memory access patterns
generate_access_sequence()


TileDistribution
Tile-based processing
get_tile_coordinates(), get_num_tiles()


TileWindow
Windowed tile access
get_window_data(), slide_window()




For detailed documentation of each module, click on the links above. Each page includes:

Class definitions with full method signatures
Usage examples with runnable code
Parameter descriptions and return values
Related concepts and cross-references

title: PythonCK Learning Path
text:
This document provides a structured learning path to understand all concepts in PythonCK, culminating in the complete understanding of tile_distr_thread_mapping.py - which demonstrates how GPU threads coordinate to process tensor data efficiently.


The final example shows: - How tile windows load data from tensors - How sweep operations iterate over distributed data - How thread coordination works in GPU kernels - The difference between old problematic APIs and clean modern APIs






Buffer Views - Memory abstraction
Tensor Coordinates - Multi-dimensional indexing

Tensor Descriptors - Layout transformations
Tensor Views - Unified access interface





Tile Distribution Encoding - How data is encoded for distribution
Tile Distribution - Parallel processing coordination
Static Distributed Tensors - Thread-local data management





Tile Windows - Windowed tensor access
Sweep Operations - Coordinated iteration
Thread Mapping - Complete GPU coordination








File: pytensor/buffer_view.py
Concept: Memory abstraction layer






Key Learning: Buffer views provide the lowest-level memory access abstraction, supporting different address spaces (GLOBAL, LDS, VGPR) that correspond to different GPU memory hierarchies.
Next: Learn how to index into this memory systematically.




File: pytensor/tensor_coordinate.py
Concept: Multi-dimensional indexing system






Key Learning: Coordinates provide systematic access to multi-dimensional data with support for transformations between different index spaces.
Next: Learn how coordinates are transformed through different tensor layouts.




File: pytensor/tensor_descriptor.py
Concept: Layout transformations and tensor structure






Key Learning: Descriptors define how multi-dimensional tensor coordinates map to linear memory addresses, enabling complex layout transformations.
Next: Combine buffers and descriptors for unified tensor access.




File: pytensor/tensor_view.py
Concept: Unified tensor access interface






Key Learning: Tensor views combine buffer views (memory) with tensor descriptors (layout) to provide high-level tensor access.
Next: Learn how tensor data is distributed across parallel processing elements.




File: pytensor/tile_distribution_encoding.py
Concept: Mathematical encoding of data distribution






Key Learning: Encoding defines the mathematical mapping between different coordinate spaces (P, Y, R, H) that enable parallel data distribution.
Next: Create actual tile distributions from encodings.




File: pytensor/tile_distribution.py
Concept: Parallel processing coordination






Key Learning: Tile distributions coordinate how different processing elements (threads/warps) access different portions of tensor data.
Next: Learn how individual threads manage their local data.




File: pytensor/static_distributed_tensor.py
Concept: Thread-local data management






Key Learning: Each thread/processing element has its own local tensor that holds a specific subset of the global data.
Next: Learn how threads access windowed portions of tensors.




File: pytensor/tile_window.py
Concept: Windowed tensor access






Key Learning: Tile windows allow threads to access specific rectangular regions of tensors, with the distribution determining which thread sees which data.
Next: Learn how to iterate over distributed data systematically.




File: pytensor/sweep_tile.py
Concept: Coordinated iteration over distributed data






Key Learning: Sweep operations provide systematic iteration over distributed tensor data, ensuring each thread processes its assigned elements.
Next: Understand the complete thread mapping pipeline.




File: tile_distr_thread_mapping.py
Concept: Complete GPU thread coordination
Now you‚Äôre ready to understand the complete example! The tile_distr_thread_mapping.py file demonstrates:










You now understand the complete PythonCK pipeline:

Memory (buffer views) provides the foundation
Indexing (coordinates) enables systematic access

Layout (descriptors) handles transformations
Access (tensor views) unifies the interface
Distribution (encoding & tile distribution) coordinates parallelism
Threading (static distributed tensors) manages local data
Windowing (tile windows) provides regional access
Iteration (sweep operations) processes data systematically

The tile_distr_thread_mapping.py example shows how all these concepts work together to enable efficient GPU tensor processing, where hundreds or thousands of threads coordinate to process large tensors in parallel.




Experiment with different thread positions in the examples
Try different tile distribution encodings
Explore the visualization tools in tile_distribution/
Build your own tensor operations using these primitives

You‚Äôre now equipped to understand and build sophisticated GPU tensor operations!

title: PythonCK Learning Path
text:
üéØ Ultimate Goal: Understanding tile_distr_thread_mapping.py
The final example demonstrates complete GPU thread coordination - how threads cooperatively process tensor data using tile windows, sweep operations, and distribution strategies.

title: PythonCK Learning Path
text:
üìö Learning Path Overview

Phase 1: Foundation (Memory & Indexing)

Buffer Views - Memory abstraction
Tensor Coordinates - Multi-dimensional indexing

Tensor Descriptors - Layout transformations
Tensor Views - Unified access interface



Phase 2: Distribution (Parallel Processing)

Tile Distribution Encoding - How data is encoded for distribution
Tile Distribution - Parallel processing coordination
Static Distributed Tensors - Thread-local data management



Phase 3: Advanced Operations (GPU Coordination)

Tile Windows - Windowed tensor access
Sweep Operations - Coordinated iteration
Thread Mapping - Complete GPU coordination

title: PythonCK Learning Path
text:
üîß Detailed Learning Path

1. Buffer Views
File: pytensor/buffer_view.py
Concept: Memory abstraction layer






Key Learning: Buffer views provide the lowest-level memory access abstraction, supporting different address spaces (GLOBAL, LDS, VGPR) that correspond to different GPU memory hierarchies.
Next: Learn how to index into this memory systematically.



2. Tensor Coordinates
File: pytensor/tensor_coordinate.py
Concept: Multi-dimensional indexing system






Key Learning: Coordinates provide systematic access to multi-dimensional data with support for transformations between different index spaces.
Next: Learn how coordinates are transformed through different tensor layouts.



3. Tensor Descriptors
File: pytensor/tensor_descriptor.py
Concept: Layout transformations and tensor structure






Key Learning: Descriptors define how multi-dimensional tensor coordinates map to linear memory addresses, enabling complex layout transformations.
Next: Combine buffers and descriptors for unified tensor access.



4. Tensor Views
File: pytensor/tensor_view.py
Concept: Unified tensor access interface






Key Learning: Tensor views combine buffer views (memory) with tensor descriptors (layout) to provide high-level tensor access.
Next: Learn how tensor data is distributed across parallel processing elements.



5. Tile Distribution Encoding
File: pytensor/tile_distribution_encoding.py
Concept: Mathematical encoding of data distribution






Key Learning: Encoding defines the mathematical mapping between different coordinate spaces (P, Y, R, H) that enable parallel data distribution.
Next: Create actual tile distributions from encodings.



6. Tile Distribution
File: pytensor/tile_distribution.py
Concept: Parallel processing coordination






Key Learning: Tile distributions coordinate how different processing elements (threads/warps) access different portions of tensor data.
Next: Learn how individual threads manage their local data.



7. Static Distributed Tensors
File: pytensor/static_distributed_tensor.py
Concept: Thread-local data management






Key Learning: Each thread/processing element has its own local tensor that holds a specific subset of the global data.
Next: Learn how threads access windowed portions of tensors.



8. Tile Windows
File: pytensor/tile_window.py
Concept: Windowed tensor access






Key Learning: Tile windows allow threads to access specific rectangular regions of tensors, with the distribution determining which thread sees which data.
Next: Learn how to iterate over distributed data systematically.



9. Sweep Operations
File: pytensor/sweep_tile.py
Concept: Coordinated iteration over distributed data






Key Learning: Sweep operations provide systematic iteration over distributed tensor data, ensuring each thread processes its assigned elements.
Next: Understand the complete thread mapping pipeline.



10. Thread Mapping - The Complete Picture
File: tile_distr_thread_mapping.py
Concept: Complete GPU thread coordination
Now you‚Äôre ready to understand the complete example! The tile_distr_thread_mapping.py file demonstrates:

title: PythonCK Learning Path
text:
üèÜ Congratulations!
You now understand the complete PythonCK pipeline:

Memory (buffer views) provides the foundation
Indexing (coordinates) enables systematic access

Layout (descriptors) handles transformations
Access (tensor views) unifies the interface
Distribution (encoding & tile distribution) coordinates parallelism
Threading (static distributed tensors) manages local data
Windowing (tile windows) provides regional access
Iteration (sweep operations) processes data systematically

The tile_distr_thread_mapping.py example shows how all these concepts work together to enable efficient GPU tensor processing, where hundreds or thousands of threads coordinate to process large tensors in parallel.

You‚Äôre now equipped to understand and build sophisticated GPU tensor operations!

title: PythonCK Learning Path
text:
üìö Reorganized Learning Path

Phase 1: Foundation (Memory & Basic Indexing)

Buffer Views - Memory abstraction layer
Tensor Transforms - The building blocks for coordinate transformations
Tensor Descriptors - Layout configuration and transformations
Tensor Coordinates - Final memory-mapped coordinates with offsets
Tensor Adaptors - The transformation engines that execute descriptors
Tensor Adaptor Coordinates - Result containers for transformed indices/offsets



Phase 2: Advanced Indexing (Requires Descriptors)

Advanced Coordinate Operations - move_tensor_coordinate and transform-dependent operations
Tensor Views - Unified access interface



Phase 3: Distribution (Parallel Processing)

Tile Distribution Encoding - Mathematical encoding framework
Tile Distribution Deep Dive - make_static_tile_distribution, adaptors, descriptors
Static Distributed Tensors - Thread-local data management



Phase 4: Advanced Operations (GPU Coordination)

Tile Windows Deep Dive - precompute, load, descriptor integration
Sweep Operations - Coordinated iteration patterns
Complete Thread Mapping - Understanding the full pipeline

title: PythonCK Learning Path
text:
üîÑ Key Restructuring Changes

Logical Learning Order

Before: Basic Coordinates ‚Üí Descriptors ‚Üí Advanced Coordinates (‚ùå Mixed concepts)
After: Transforms ‚Üí Descriptors ‚Üí Coordinates ‚Üí Adaptors ‚Üí Adaptor Coordinates (‚úÖ Clear flow)



Conceptual Flow

Tensor Transforms: The building blocks for coordinate transformations (Embed, Unmerge, Merge, Replicate)
TensorDescriptor: Configuration/metadata for transformations (what to do)
TensorCoordinate: Final memory-mapped coordinates with offsets (what users work with)
TensorAdaptor: Transformation engine that executes descriptors (how to do it)
TensorAdaptorCoordinate: Result containers for transformed indices/offsets (intermediate results)



Dependency-Aware Ordering

Before: Coordinates ‚Üí Descriptors (‚ùå Wrong dependency order)
After: Descriptors ‚Üí Coordinates ‚Üí Adaptors ‚Üí Adaptor Coordinates (‚úÖ Correct)



Focused Pages

Before: Long pages with multiple concepts
After: One concept per page with deep explanations



Transform Examples

Complete to_upper/to_lower examples for all transforms
Visual demonstrations of coordinate transformations



Deep Integration Examples

How precompute uses both tensor and distribution descriptors
Complete breakdown of make_static_tile_distribution
Links to interactive apps

title: PythonCK Learning Path
text:
üéì Learning Strategy

Follow the order strictly - later concepts build on earlier ones
Run all examples - hands-on understanding is crucial
Experiment with parameters - modify examples to see effects
Use the apps - tensor_transform_app and app for visualization

title: Buffer View
text:
Buffer View Integration
Buffer views serve as the foundation for all tensor operations in PythonCK. They provide the memory abstraction that higher-level components like tensor views and tile windows build upon.

title: Tensor Coordinate System Deep Dive
text:
Architecture Overview
The coordinate system consists of three levels forming a hierarchy:

Top Level: User-visible tensor indices (e.g., [i, j, k] for a 3D tensor)
Hidden Level: Intermediate transformation space that enables complex layouts
Bottom Level: Memory layout indices (linear offsets or multi-dimensional memory coordinates)

This three-level design allows arbitrary transformations between user coordinates and memory layout while maintaining mathematical rigor.

title: Tensor Coordinate System Deep Dive
text:
Core Classes

MultiIndex: The Foundation
MultiIndex is the basic container for multi-dimensional indices:








TensorAdaptorCoordinate: General Transformation Tracking
TensorAdaptorCoordinate is the general-purpose coordinate system that handles arbitrary mappings between top and bottom dimensions through hidden space:








TensorCoordinate: Specialized for Tensors
TensorCoordinate extends TensorAdaptorCoordinate with the constraint that the bottom dimension is always a single linear offset for memory addressing:

title: Tensor Coordinate System Deep Dive
text: Key Differences: TensorAdaptorCoordinate vs TensorCoordinate

title: Tensor Coordinate System Deep Dive
text:
Coordinate Creation Functions
The coordinate system provides three main ways to create coordinates:
1. Direct construction - What we‚Äôve covered so far: - TensorCoordinate(ndim_hidden, top_ids, idx_hidden) - TensorAdaptorCoordinate(ndim_hidden, bottom_ids, top_ids, idx_hidden)
2. From adaptors - Requires TensorAdaptor knowledge: - make_tensor_adaptor_coordinate(adaptor, top_index) - Covered in Advanced Coordinate Operations
3. From descriptors - Requires TensorDescriptor knowledge: - make_tensor_coordinate(descriptor, top_index) - Covered in Advanced Coordinate Operations
Note: Functions 2 and 3 require understanding of TensorAdaptor and TensorDescriptor concepts first.

title: Tensor Coordinate System Deep Dive
text: Coordinate Movement

title: Tensor Coordinate System Deep Dive
text:
Coordinate Validation
The system provides multiple levels of validation:
1. adaptor_coordinate_is_valid() - Checks top index bounds - Validates through all transformations - Complete validity check
2. coordinate_has_valid_offset() - Alias for adaptor_coordinate_is_valid - Specifically for TensorCoordinate
3. adaptor_coordinate_is_valid_assuming_top_index_is_valid() - Skips top bounds checking - Only validates transformations - Performance optimization
4. coordinate_has_valid_offset_assuming_top_index_is_valid() - TensorCoordinate version of above - Used in tight loops
Example coordinate for validation: - Top index: [1, 2] - Would be validated against tensor bounds and transforms

title: Tensor Coordinate System Deep Dive
text:
Practical Usage Patterns

Pattern 1: Basic Tensor Indexing
Workflow: 1. Create coordinate from tensor descriptor and user index 2. Use coordinate.get_offset() for memory addressing 3. Access buffer_view[offset] for element
Example: - User wants element at: [5, 3] - ‚Üí make_tensor_coordinate(descriptor, user_index) - ‚Üí coordinate.get_offset() ‚Üí memory_offset - ‚Üí buffer[memory_offset] ‚Üí element_value


Pattern 2: Tensor Iteration
Workflow: 1. Create initial coordinate 2. Loop with move_tensor_coordinate() 3. Use returned offset changes for efficient addressing
Example:
for i in range(height):
    for j in range(width):
        step = MultiIndex(2, [0, 1])  # Move right
        offset_change = move_tensor_coordinate(desc, coord, step)
        memory_address += offset_change
        # Process element at new position


Pattern 3: Transformation Chains
Workflow: 1. Build TensorDescriptor with transform chain 2. Create coordinate with make_tensor_coordinate() 3. Coordinate automatically handles all transformations
Example: Transposed, padded, strided tensor - User index [i,j] ‚Üí - EmbedTransform (stride) ‚Üí - PadTransform (padding) ‚Üí - MergeTransform (transpose) ‚Üí - Memory offset
All handled transparently by coordinate system!

title: Tensor Coordinate System Deep Dive
text:
Integration with Other Components
The coordinate system integrates with all PythonCK components:
üîó Buffer Views: - Coordinates ‚Üí memory offsets ‚Üí buffer element access
üîó Tensor Descriptors: - Descriptors define transformations ‚Üí coordinates apply them
üîó Tile Distributions: - Thread coordinates ‚Üí tensor coordinates ‚Üí memory coordinates
üîó Tile Windows: - Window coordinates ‚Üí tensor coordinates ‚Üí data loading
üîó Sweep Operations: - Iteration patterns ‚Üí coordinate movement ‚Üí memory traversal

title: Tensor Coordinate System Deep Dive
text:
Summary
The tensor coordinate system provides:

Three-Level Hierarchy: Clear separation of concerns between user, transformation, and memory spaces
Two Coordinate Types: General adaptors for flexibility, specialized tensors for efficiency
Complete Function Set: Creation, movement, validation, and conversion functions
Performance Optimization: Validation levels for different performance requirements
Universal Integration: Foundation for all tensor operations in PythonCK

Understanding this system enables effective use of all higher-level PythonCK components and is essential for implementing custom tensor operations.

title: Tensor Coordinate System Deep Dive
text:
Next Steps

Explore Tensor Descriptors to understand how transformations are defined
Learn Advanced Coordinate Operations for descriptor-dependent functions like make_tensor_adaptor_coordinate and make_tensor_coordinate
Study Tile Distribution to see coordinates in parallel processing
Practice with interactive applications that demonstrate coordinate usage

The coordinate system is the mathematical backbone that makes PythonCK‚Äôs advanced tensor operations possible!

title: Advanced Coordinate Operations
section: üèóÔ∏è Coordinate Creation from Descriptors and Adaptors
text:
üèóÔ∏è Coordinate Creation from Descriptors and Adaptors

make_tensor_coordinate: Descriptor-Based Creation
Creates coordinates from tensor descriptors:








make_tensor_adaptor_coordinate: Adaptor-Based Creation
Creates coordinates from tensor adaptors (more general than descriptors):








Key Differences: Descriptor vs Adaptor Creation
make_tensor_coordinate: - Takes TensorDescriptor - Always creates TensorCoordinate - Bottom dimension is single offset - Simpler, tensor-specific
make_tensor_adaptor_coordinate: - Takes TensorAdaptor - Creates TensorAdaptorCoordinate - Can have multiple bottom dimensions - More general, flexible
Relationship: - make_tensor_coordinate() calls make_tensor_adaptor_coordinate() internally - then converts result to TensorCoordinate

title: Tensor Coordinate System Deep Dive
text:
Foundation: Coordinate Containers

MultiIndex: The Foundation
MultiIndex is the basic container for multi-dimensional indices:








TensorAdaptorCoordinate: Coordinate Container (Not a Transformation Engine)
TensorAdaptorCoordinate is a general-purpose coordinate container for the hidden space. It: - Stores the current coordinate in the hidden space - Knows which hidden dimensions correspond to top (user) and bottom (memory) indices - Does not own or perform any transformations - Is produced by a TensorAdaptor (which owns the transformation chain)

Note: All transformation logic lives in the TensorAdaptor. The TensorAdaptorCoordinate is just a result container for the indices after transformations are applied.



TensorCoordinate: Specialized for Tensors
TensorCoordinate is a specialization of TensorAdaptorCoordinate for the common case where the bottom dimension is a single linear offset (for memory addressing):

title: Advanced Coordinate Operations
text:
Coordinate Movement
Coordinate movement is essential for iterating through tensor spaces, especially when transformations are involved. Movement requires knowledge of the descriptor or adaptor, since the transformation chain determines how steps in the top space map to changes in the hidden and bottom spaces.
Example:







Note: Movement is only meaningful after you understand how descriptors and adaptors define the mapping between top, hidden, and bottom spaces.


These operations bridge the gap between mathematical transforms and practical tensor manipulation!

title: Tensor Adaptor Coordinate: The Result Container
text:

A Tensor Adaptor Coordinate stores the results of coordinate transformations:
Input Index ‚Üí Tensor Adaptor ‚Üí Tensor Adaptor Coordinate ‚Üí Final Tensor Coordinate
The adaptor coordinate contains: - Top Index: The original input coordinates - Bottom Index: The transformed output coordinates
- Hidden Index: Internal storage for the transformation results

title: Tensor Transforms: The Building Blocks
text:
üéØ Core Concept
A Tensor Transform is a mathematical operation that converts coordinates between two spaces:
Upper Coordinates ‚Üê‚Üí Transform ‚Üê‚Üí Lower Coordinates
Each transform has two operations: - to_lower: Upper coordinate ‚Üí Lower coordinate (forward transform) - to_upper: Lower coordinate ‚Üí Upper coordinate (backward transform)

title: Tensor Transforms: The Building Blocks
text:
üîß Transform Types

1. EmbedTransform: Strided Layout
Purpose: Maps multi-dimensional coordinates to linear memory with custom strides.







Forward Transformation (to_lower)








Backward Transformation (to_upper)








Visual Example









2. UnmergeTransform: Packed Layout
Purpose: Unpacks a linear index into multi-dimensional coordinates.







Forward Transformation (to_lower)








Backward Transformation (to_upper)









3. MergeTransform: Dimension Merging
Purpose: Merges multiple dimensions into a single dimension.
Key Difference from EmbedTransform: - EmbedTransform: Maps multi-dimensional coordinates to linear memory with custom strides (preserves the original coordinate structure) - MergeTransform: Collapses multiple dimensions into a single dimension (changes the coordinate structure)







Forward Transformation (to_lower)








Backward Transformation (to_upper)









4. ReplicateTransform: Broadcasting
Purpose: Broadcasts smaller dimensions to larger dimensions (replication).







Forward Transformation (to_lower)








Backward Transformation (to_upper)

text:

They enable optimization - Understanding transforms helps optimize GPU memory access

Tensor Transforms are the mathematical building blocks that make all coordinate operations possible. Master these four transform types to understand how PythonCK maps between different coordinate spaces.

title: Tensor Transforms: The Building Blocks
text:
üßÆ Symbolic Formulas with SymPy
For each transform, we can use its sympy_upper_to_lower and sympy_lower_to_upper methods to generate symbolic formulas for the coordinate transformations. Below, we show both the symbolic Python output and the LaTeX representation for each direction.

title: Tensor Transforms: The Building Blocks
text:
Tensor transforms are the fundamental mathematical operations that map between different coordinate spaces in PythonCK. Each transform defines how coordinates are converted from one representation to another.


PythonCK provides four core transform types:

EmbedTransform: Maps multi-dimensional coordinates to linear memory with custom strides
UnmergeTransform: Packs multi-dimensional coordinates into linear indices
MergeTransform: Splits linear indices into multi-dimensional coordinates

ReplicateTransform: Broadcasts single values to multiple dimensions






Purpose: Maps multi-dimensional coordinates to linear memory with custom strides.
Example: A 2√ó3 matrix with strides [6, 1] - Upper dimensions: [2, 3] (2√ó3 matrix) - Lower dimensions: [1] (linear memory) - Strides: [6, 1] (custom memory layout)
Forward Transformation (to_lower): - Input: [1, 2] (row 1, column 2) - Output: [8] (linear index) - Calculation: 1√ó6 + 2√ó1 = 8
Backward Transformation (to_upper): - Input: [8] (linear index 8) - Output: [1, 2] (recovered 2D coordinate)
Visual Example: - [0,0] ‚Üí 0 (calculation: 0√ó6 + 0√ó1 = 0) - [0,1] ‚Üí 1 (calculation: 0√ó6 + 1√ó1 = 1) - [1,0] ‚Üí 6 (calculation: 1√ó6 + 0√ó1 = 6) - [1,2] ‚Üí 8 (calculation: 1√ó6 + 2√ó1 = 8)



Purpose: Packs multi-dimensional coordinates into linear indices using row-major order.
Example: A 2√ó3 matrix packed to linear - Upper dimensions: [2, 3] (2√ó3 matrix) - Lower dimensions: [1] (packed linear index) - Packing: row-major order (row√ó3 + col)
Forward Transformation (to_lower): - Input: [1, 2] (row 1, column 2) - Output: [5] (packed index) - Calculation: 1√ó3 + 2 = 5
Backward Transformation (to_upper): - Input: [5] (packed index 5) - Output: [1, 2] (recovered 2D coordinate)



Purpose: Splits linear indices into multi-dimensional coordinates.
Key Difference from EmbedTransform: - EmbedTransform: Maps multi-dimensional coordinates to linear memory with custom strides (preserves the original coordinate structure) - MergeTransform: Collapses multiple dimensions into a single dimension (changes the coordinate structure)
Example: Linear index split to 2√ó3 - Upper dimensions: [1] (single dimension) - Lower dimensions: [2, 3] (split into 2√ó3) - Splitting: first dimension ‚Üí row, second dimension ‚Üí column
Forward Transformation (to_lower): - Input: [5] (single index 5) - Output: [1, 2] (split into 2D) - Calculation: row = 5 √∑ 3 = 1, col = 5 % 3 = 2
Backward Transformation (to_upper): - Input: [1, 2] (2D coordinate [1, 2]) - Output: [5] (merged single index) - Calculation: 1√ó3 + 2 = 5



Purpose: Broadcasts single values to multiple dimensions.
Example: Broadcasting to 6 positions - Upper dimensions: [6] (larger dimension) - Lower dimensions: [0] (no lower dimensions - broadcasting) - Broadcasting: single value repeated to fill 6 positions
Forward Transformation (to_lower): - Input: [4] (index 4 in 6D) - Output: [] (empty - no lower dimensions) - Note: ReplicateTransform has no lower dimensions
Backward Transformation (to_upper): - Input: [] (empty lower coordinate) - Output: [0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0] (all zeros in 6D) - Note: ReplicateTransform broadcasts single value to all positions






Each transform can be validated by checking that forward and backward transformations are consistent:
EmbedTransform: - Test 0: [0,0] ‚Üí [0] ‚Üí [0,0] ‚úì - Test 1: [1,1] ‚Üí [7] ‚Üí [1,1] ‚úì - Test 2: [1,2] ‚Üí [8] ‚Üí [1,2] ‚úì
UnmergeTransform: - Test 0: [0,0] ‚Üí [0] ‚Üí [0,0] ‚úì - Test 1: [1,1] ‚Üí [4] ‚Üí [1,1] ‚úì - Test 2: [1,2] ‚Üí [5] ‚Üí [1,2] ‚úì
MergeTransform: - Test 0: [0] ‚Üí [0,0] ‚Üí [0] ‚úì - Test 1: [3] ‚Üí [1,0] ‚Üí [3] ‚úì - Test 2: [5] ‚Üí [1,2] ‚Üí [5] ‚úì
ReplicateTransform: - Test 0: [0] ‚Üí [] ‚Üí [0] ‚úì - Test 1: [3] ‚Üí [] ‚Üí [0] ‚úó (not invertible) - Test 2: [5] ‚Üí [] ‚Üí [0] ‚úó (not invertible)
Note: ReplicateTransform is not invertible by design - all upper indices map to the same lower index (empty), and the backward mapping always returns zeros.




Each transform provides symbolic methods for mathematical analysis:
EmbedTransform: - Upper ‚Üí Lower: u0*6 + u1*1 - Lower ‚Üí Upper: (l0//6, l0%6)
UnmergeTransform: - Upper ‚Üí Lower: u0*3 + u1 - Lower ‚Üí Upper: (l0//3, l0%3)
MergeTransform: - Lower ‚Üí Upper: l0*3 + l1 - Upper ‚Üí Lower: (u0//3, u0%3)
ReplicateTransform: - Upper ‚Üí Lower: [] (empty) - Lower ‚Üí Upper: [0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0] (all zeros)



Understanding individual transforms is crucial because:

They are the building blocks - All complex coordinate operations are built from these basic transforms
They define memory layouts - Different transforms create different memory access patterns
They enable optimization - Understanding transforms helps optimize GPU memory access
They support complex operations - Multiple transforms can be chained for sophisticated layouts




Transforms are used throughout PythonCK:

Tensor Descriptors combine transforms to define tensor layouts
Tensor Adaptors execute transforms to perform coordinate conversions
Tile Distributions use transforms to map between coordinate spaces
Memory Access relies on transforms for address calculations




Now that you understand the individual transforms, you can explore: - Tensor Descriptors - How transforms are combined into layout definitions - Tensor Coordinates - How transforms create final memory-mapped coordinates - Tensor Adaptors - How transforms are executed as transformation engines

Tensor Transforms are the mathematical building blocks that make all coordinate operations possible. Master these four transform types to understand how PythonCK maps between different coordinate spaces.

title: Tensor Transforms: The Building Blocks
text:
PythonCK provides four core transform types:

EmbedTransform: Maps multi-dimensional coordinates to linear memory with custom strides
UnmergeTransform: Packs multi-dimensional coordinates into linear indices
MergeTransform: Splits linear indices into multi-dimensional coordinates

ReplicateTransform: Broadcasts single values to multiple dimensions

title: Tensor Transforms: The Building Blocks
text:
Each transform provides symbolic methods for mathematical analysis:
EmbedTransform: - Upper ‚Üí Lower: u0*6 + u1*1 - Lower ‚Üí Upper: (l0//6, l0%6)
UnmergeTransform: - Upper ‚Üí Lower: u0*3 + u1 - Lower ‚Üí Upper: (l0//3, l0%3)
MergeTransform: - Lower ‚Üí Upper: l0*3 + l1 - Upper ‚Üí Lower: (u0//3, u0%3)
ReplicateTransform: - Upper ‚Üí Lower: [] (empty) - Lower ‚Üí Upper: [0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0] (all zeros)

title: TensorAdaptor: The Transformation Engine
text:
What does a TensorAdaptor do?
A TensorAdaptor manages the transformation pipeline from top coordinates (user-facing, logical indices) to bottom coordinates (memory layout, physical indices).

Coordinate transformation: Provides calculate_bottom_index() method to transform from top-level indices to bottom-level (memory) indices.
Transform chain management: Internally manages a sequence of transforms but does not allow adding/removing transforms after creation.
Hidden dimension tracking: Maintains the mapping between transform inputs/outputs through hidden dimension IDs.


Key Methods

calculate_bottom_index(idx_top): Transform top coordinates to bottom coordinates
get_num_of_transform(): Get the number of transforms in the chain
get_num_of_top_dimension(): Get number of top (user-facing) dimensions
get_num_of_bottom_dimension(): Get number of bottom (memory) dimensions
get_num_of_hidden_dimension(): Get total number of hidden dimensions

title: Tensor Adaptor: The Transformation Engine
text:
Where is TensorAdaptor used?

TensorDescriptor: The descriptor extends TensorAdaptor to add information about the element space (size, vectorization, etc.).
TileDistribution, TensorView, and other advanced features: All rely on the adaptor to perform coordinate conversions.

title: Tensor Adaptor: The Transformation Engine
text:
Example: Chaining Transforms
Suppose you want to map a 2D user coordinate to a linear memory offset, possibly with some intermediate tiling or permutation. The TensorAdaptor lets you define this as a sequence of transforms, and then handles all the bookkeeping for you.

Next: TensorDescriptor ‚Äî how it extends the adaptor and adds memory layout information.

title: TensorDescriptor: The Complete Layout Description
text:
What is a TensorDescriptor?

Extends TensorAdaptor: Inherits all the transformation logic and hierarchy management from TensorAdaptor.
Adds element space information: Knows the total number of elements, vectorization guarantees, and other memory layout details.
Defines the full layout: Combines a sequence of transforms with memory size and access properties.

title: Tensor Descriptors
text:
How does TensorDescriptor extend TensorAdaptor?

All TensorDescriptors are TensorAdaptors, but not all adaptors are descriptors.
TensorAdaptor: Handles coordinate transformations and hidden dimension tracking.
TensorDescriptor: Adds memory size, vectorization, and layout guarantees on top of the transformation engine.

title: Tensor Descriptors
text:
Key Differences: TensorAdaptor vs TensorDescriptor








Feature
TensorAdaptor
TensorDescriptor




Coordinate transforms
Yes
Yes


Hidden dimension mgmt
Yes
Yes


Memory size info
No
Yes


Vectorization info
No
Yes


Used for‚Ä¶
General transforms
Full tensor layout

title: TensorDescriptor: The Complete Layout Description
text:
Helper Functions for Descriptors
PythonCK provides several helper functions to quickly create common tensor layouts:

make_naive_tensor_descriptor: Create a descriptor for a standard (strided) tensor layout with custom strides.
make_naive_tensor_descriptor_packed: Create a descriptor for a packed (contiguous) layout.
make_naive_tensor_descriptor_aligned: Create a descriptor with alignment constraints.
transform_tensor_descriptor: Apply additional transforms to an existing descriptor.

These functions let you easily define the most common tensor layouts, or build up more complex ones by chaining transforms.

Next: See Tensor Coordinates for how descriptors and adaptors are used to create and manipulate actual tensor indices.

title: TensorAdaptor: The Transformation Engine
text:
Differences: TensorAdaptor vs TensorDescriptor

TensorAdaptor: Handles coordinate transformations and hidden dimension tracking. It is the general-purpose transformation engine.
TensorDescriptor: Extends TensorAdaptor to add memory size, vectorization, and layout guarantees. It is used for full tensor layout definitions.

Next: TensorDescriptor ‚Äî how to define a full tensor layout, first using the constructor, then with helper functions.

title: TensorAdaptor: The Transformation Engine
text:
TensorAdaptor vs TensorDescriptor







TensorAdaptor
TensorDescriptor




Manages coordinate transformations
Extends TensorAdaptor with element space info


Has calculate_bottom_index()
Adds calculate_offset(), get_lengths()


Tracks hidden dimension mappings
Adds element space size and vector guarantees


Used as building block
Used for complete tensor layout description


No element space concept
Knows total number of elements

title: TensorAdaptor: The Transformation Engine
text:
When to Use TensorAdaptor

Building coordinate transformation pipelines: When you need to chain multiple transforms
Custom tensor layouts: When standard layouts don‚Äôt meet your needs

As components in larger systems: TensorDescriptor internally uses TensorAdaptor
Research and experimentation: When exploring new transformation patterns

TensorAdaptor provides the foundation for coordinate transformations, while TensorDescriptor builds upon it to provide complete tensor layout descriptions for practical use.
Next: TensorDescriptor ‚Äî Learn how TensorDescriptor extends TensorAdaptor with element space information.

title: Tensor Coordinates
text:
What is a TensorCoordinate?
A TensorCoordinate is the end product of the tensor transformation pipeline:
Input Index ‚Üí Transforms ‚Üí TensorCoordinate (Index + Offset)
Key characteristics: - Stores the final index: The transformed multi-dimensional coordinate - Stores the linear offset: The final memory location after all transformations - Extends TensorAdaptorCoordinate: Inherits transformation tracking but focuses on the final result - Always has a single bottom dimension: The linear offset is stored in hidden dimension [0]

title: Tensor Coordinates
text:
Why TensorCoordinate Matters
After complex transformations (embedding, merging, unmerging, etc.), you need: 1. The final index: Where you are in the logical tensor space 2. The linear offset: Where to actually access memory
TensorCoordinate provides both pieces of information in a single, convenient container.
